thinkers.name: Michael Levin
thinkers.context: Director of the Allen Discovery Center at Tufts University; primary author exploring how cellular competency and morphogenetic problem-solving shape evolution.

thinkers.name: William James
thinkers.context: Defined intelligence as 'the ability to reach the same goal by different means'; his definition frames the paper's understanding of multiscale competency.

thinkers.name: Shunryu Suzuki
thinkers.context: Quoted on 'Beginner's Mind' to illustrate how biological systems operate with flexibility rather than hardwired expectations.

thinkers.name: Douglas Blackiston
thinkers.context: Researcher involved in Xenobot development; provided images demonstrating morphogenetic capabilities of frog cells.

thinkers.name: Alan Turing
thinkers.context: Pioneering work on intelligence in unconventional embodiments and autopoiesis in biological form during embryogenesis.

thinkers.name: Charles Darwin
thinkers.context: Quoted regarding adaptability and evolution; foundational to discussion of evolutionary mechanisms and the origins of species.

thinkers.name: Eva Jablonka
thinkers.context: Contributor to understanding epigenetic inheritance and evolutionary transitions in learning and cognition.

thinkers.name: Stuart Newman
thinkers.context: Work on dynamical patterning modules and evolutionary transitions in individuality.

thinkers.name: Chris Fields
thinkers.context: Collaborator on scale-free biology, competency navigation, and multiscale intelligence frameworks.

thinkers.name: Joshua Bongard
thinkers.context: Collaborator on Xenobots, reconfigurable organisms, and evolutionary computation approaches to design.

thinkers.name: Giovanni Pezzulo
thinkers.context: Contributor to understanding top-down models, downward causation, and active inference in biological systems.

thinkers.name: Karl Friston
thinkers.context: Developer of Free Energy Principle and Active Inference frameworks; applies variational methods to understanding biological self-organization.

thinkers.name: Stuart Kauffman
thinkers.context: Pioneer in Boolean networks and complex adaptive systems; contributes to understanding evolutionary dynamics and emergent properties.

thinkers.name: Eörs Szathmáry
thinkers.context: Co-developer of Evolutionary Transitions in Individuality theory; explores major transitions in evolution and emergence of complexity.

thinkers.name: Rodney Pfeifer
thinkers.context: Developer of Morphological Computation concept; pioneers embodied AI and bio-inspired robotics.

thinkers.name: Daniel Dennett
thinkers.context: Philosopher contributing to minimal intelligence and consciousness theories.

thinkers.name: Hector Zenil
thinkers.context: Researcher on cellular computation and algorithmic information dynamics.

thinkers.name: Josh Bongard
thinkers.context: Co-developer of xenobots and sim-to-real transfer methods; explores evolved digital and physical systems.

thinkers.name: Robert Rosen
thinkers.context: Contributes to understanding evolvability and spaces of possible organisms.

thinkers.name: Stephen Jay Gould
thinkers.context: Evolutionary theorist; work on ontogeny and phylogeny relevant to developmental evolution.

thinkers.name: Ned Newman
thinkers.context: Researcher on morphogenesis, agency in evolution, and Form-Function-Agency theory.

concepts.name: Multiscale Competency Architecture
concepts.context: Framework describing how cells, tissues, and organs exhibit problem-solving abilities across physiological, transcriptional, and anatomical spaces.

concepts.name: Developmental Plasticity
concepts.context: Ability of biological systems to adjust to perturbations and accomplish adaptive tasks despite changes in circumstances, genetics, or cell number.

concepts.name: Agential Material
concepts.context: Biological substrate (cells, tissues) that possesses autonomous capabilities and problem-solving competencies, not passive components.

concepts.name: Cellular Competency
concepts.context: Problem-solving and adaptive behavioral capabilities of cells derived from ancestral unicellular organisms.

concepts.name: Collective Intelligence
concepts.context: Problem-solving capacity emerging from coordination of multiple agents (cells, tissues) working toward shared morphogenetic goals.

concepts.name: Morphogenesis
concepts.context: Developmental process by which cells collectively generate form and function; operates as cybernetic system pursuing homeostatic setpoints.

concepts.name: Developmental Bioelectricity
concepts.context: Use of ion channel dynamics and bioelectric networks to compute and coordinate multicellular morphogenetic information independent of gene expression.

concepts.name: Cybernetics
concepts.context: Science of circular control and goal-directed systems; provides framework for understanding feedback mechanisms and multiscale causality in biology.

concepts.name: Homeostatic Setpoint
concepts.context: Goal state or desired anatomical/physiological configuration that cellular collectives work to achieve and maintain.

concepts.name: Regeneration
concepts.context: Process by which organisms rebuild missing or damaged structures, achieving correct target morphology despite physiological perturbations.

concepts.name: Basal Cognition
concepts.context: Study of problem-solving and adaptive behavior in simple systems, from molecular networks to single cells, revealing early evolutionary origins of intelligence.

concepts.name: Embodied Mind
concepts.context: Problem-solving and creativity emerging from physical systems interacting with their environment, not exclusively from top-down planning.

concepts.name: Inverse Problem
concepts.context: Challenge of determining which genetic changes produce desired anatomical outcomes; fundamentally unsolvable in general for complex morphogenesis.

concepts.name: Credit Assignment Problem
concepts.context: Machine learning problem of attributing credit to specific components for overall system performance; analogous to relating genotypes to phenotypes.

concepts.name: Affordances
concepts.context: Capabilities and problem-solving competencies available in biological systems that evolution can exploit for efficient navigation of phenotype space.

concepts.name: Emergence
concepts.context: Complex large-scale patterns arising from simple local rules; insufficient alone to explain morphogenetic control and evolvability.

concepts.name: Downward Causation
concepts.context: Causal influence of higher-level systems on lower-level components; enables control via goal-setting rather than micromanagement of details.

concepts.name: Intelligence
concepts.context: Ability to navigate problem spaces and reach goals by different means; extended here beyond brains to cells, tissues, and organs.

concepts.name: Metamorphosis
concepts.context: Developmental transformation of organism form; operates under same morphogenetic competency principles as embryogenesis and regeneration.

concepts.name: Cancer Suppression
concepts.context: Maintenance of tissue-level information and prevention of cellular defection; enabled by robust morphogenetic control systems.

concepts.name: Problem Space
concepts.context: Domain in which an agent solves problems; includes physiological, metabolic, transcriptional, anatomical, and behavioral spaces.

concepts.name: Reprogrammability
concepts.context: Ability of biological systems to modify their behavior and goals without changes to genetic hardware; enabled by bioelectric and other control networks.

concepts.name: Baldwin Effect
concepts.context: Process by which learned or plastic traits become canalized into genetic changes over evolutionary time.

concepts.name: Membrane Potential
concepts.context: Electrical charge difference across cell membranes; serves as high-level control parameter for morphogenetic goal-setting.

concepts.name: Ion Channels
concepts.context: Protein structures controlling ion flow across membranes; genetic targets enabling manipulation of bioelectric patterns and morphogenetic outcomes.

concepts.name: Gap Junctions
concepts.context: Intercellular connections allowing electrical and chemical communication; enable scaling of cellular competencies to tissue and organ levels.

concepts.name: Anatomical Morphospace
concepts.context: Abstract space of possible body forms; biological systems navigate this space through morphogenetic problem-solving.

concepts.name: Cybernetic Perception-Action Loop
concepts.context: Feedback mechanism where perception of current state drives action toward goal state; fundamental to morphogenetic control.

concepts.name: Connectionist Models
concepts.context: Neural network approaches to computation applicable to developmental events; enable understanding of pattern completion and memory in morphogenesis.

concepts.name: Cortical Inheritance
concepts.context: Transmission of cytoskeletal patterns across cell divisions independent of DNA; enables stable morphogenetic information storage in unicells.

concepts.name: Morphological Computation
concepts.context: Problem-solving performed by body structure and biomechanics rather than explicit neural computation; reduces burden on evolved controller.

concepts.name: Anticipatory Systems
concepts.context: Systems capable of predicting future states based on prior experience; implemented by gene-regulatory and protein-interaction networks.

concepts.name: Pattern Memory
concepts.context: Bioelectrically encoded representation of target morphology; can be rewritten without genetic change, enabling rapid exploration of morphospace.

concepts.name: Self
concepts.context: Concept of identity and boundary at multiple scales; biological agents recognize and manipulate affordances in characteristic ways.

concepts.name: Niche Construction
concepts.context: Developmental mechanism by which organisms shape their own selective environment; contributes to evolvability.

concepts.name: Morphogenetic Hacking
concepts.context: Exploitation of biological system competencies through behavior-shaping signals rather than micromanaging underlying mechanisms.

concepts.name: Chimeras
concepts.context: Organisms composed of cells from different origins; unpredictability demonstrates collective decision-making in morphogenesis.

concepts.name: Xenobots
concepts.context: Synthetic organisms derived from frog embryonic cells; exhibit novel behaviors and kinematic self-replication when freed from normal developmental constraints.

concepts.name: Hybrots
concepts.context: Hybrid biological-technological constructs; human tracheal cells forming self-motile structures capable of neural wound healing.

concepts.name: Evolvability
concepts.context: Property of systems enabling rapid and robust evolutionary change; enhanced by modularity, plasticity, and multiscale competencies.

concepts.name: Teleonomy
concepts.context: Goal-directedness in biological systems explained through naturalistic cybernetic mechanisms; does not require teleology or magic.

concepts.name: Virtual Governor
concepts.context: High-level control nodes (calcium patterns, membrane potential, tension) that represent complex functions of molecular details without 1:1 mapping.

concepts.name: Stress Sharing
concepts.context: Tissue-level mechanism distributing stress across cells; contributes to scaling of cell competencies to larger problem spaces.

concepts.name: Engrams
concepts.context: Physical substrates of memory; shared via gap junctional communication to wipe cellular individuality and enlarge network memory.

concepts.name: Neurotransmitter
concepts.context: Chemical signal used in neural and non-neural contexts; exploitable by parasites and other organisms for behavioral manipulation.

concepts.name: Ectopic Organ
concepts.context: Organ formed in anatomically abnormal location; demonstrates morphogenetic capability independent of normal developmental context.

concepts.name: Planarian Regeneration
concepts.context: Flatworms exhibiting complete body regeneration, cancer resistance, and apparent immortality; demonstrate extreme morphogenetic competency.

concepts.name: Xenopus Development
concepts.context: Model organism used to study morphogenetic control via bioelectric manipulation; demonstrates scalable competency and recruitment.

concepts.name: Play the Hand You're Dealt
concepts.context: Principle that successful developmental systems operate effectively with whatever internal and external conditions they encounter.

concepts.name: Beginner's Mind
concepts.context: Approach to morphogenesis emphasizing flexibility and real-time problem-solving rather than assumption of prior states.

concepts.name: Evolutionary Intelligence Ratchet
concepts.context: Self-reinforcing process where competency improvements make genomic quality harder to assess, driving further competency evolution.

concepts.name: Dukkha
concepts.context: Buddhist concept of suffering/stress; used metaphorically for system-level error minimization driving morphogenetic regulation.

concepts.name: Cognitive Light Cone
concepts.context: Spatio-temporal scale of goal states pursued by collective; scales with network complexity, memory, and sensory radius.

concepts.name: Bioelectric Prepattern
concepts.context: Voltage distribution across tissue encoding target morphology; instructive for patterning and functions as counterfactual memory.

concepts.name: Perceptual Bistability
concepts.context: Phenomenon where same input produces different outcomes; models stochastic phenotypes from identical genomes in developmental contexts.

concepts.name: V-Atpase
concepts.context: Proton pump whose activity controls bioelectric patterns; functionally replaceable by yeast proton pump, illustrating modularity.

concepts.name: Modularity
concepts.context: Organization of morphogenetic systems into functional units; enables decomposition of control problems and facilitates evolvability.

concepts.name: Bioelectrical Signaling
concepts.context: Use of ion channel modulation to encode morphogenetic instructions; more abstract and generalizable than molecular signals.

concepts.name: Chreods
concepts.context: Developmental pathways treated as collections of regenerative repairs toward homeostatic setpoints.

concepts.name: Epigenetic Inheritance
concepts.context: Transmission of heritable changes not encoded in DNA sequence; acknowledged as important but beyond current paper's focus.

concepts.name: Bioelectricity
concepts.context: Voltage gradients across cell membranes that serve as a collective computational medium for controlling growth, form, and pattern formation independent of genetic instructions.

concepts.name: Active Inference
concepts.context: Process by which biological systems maintain internal models and minimize surprise by actively sampling and modifying their environment through cybernetic control loops.

concepts.name: Plasticity
concepts.context: The capacity of biological systems to generate multiple phenotypes from the same genotype in response to internal or external perturbations.

concepts.name: Cryptic Variation
concepts.context: Mutations and genetic variants whose phenotypic effects are buffered by developmental regulation, maintaining genetic diversity for future adaptation.

concepts.name: Individuality
concepts.context: Fundamental property of biological systems to maintain coherent identity and boundaries through computational mechanisms at multiple scales.

concepts.name: Polycomputation
concepts.context: Using existing biological mechanisms to perform multiple distinct computational functions through different interpretations of the same substrate.

concepts.name: Constructive Neutral Evolution
concepts.context: Evolutionary process where changes to developmental control systems create new functions without requiring prior adaptive advantage.

concepts.name: Attractor State
concepts.context: Stable configuration toward which biological systems dynamically move, representing a solution in morphological or physiological problem space.

concepts.name: Cognitive Scaling
concepts.context: Progressive increase in problem-solving capacity across evolutionary time, from molecular to organismal scales.

concepts.name: Diverse Intelligence
concepts.context: Recognition of spectrum of problem-solving and creative capacities across unconventional media beyond nervous systems.

concepts.name: Cooperation
concepts.context: Reliable coordination between biological components enabled by encapsulation of competencies with clear, predictable goal states.

concepts.name: Genetic Relatedness
concepts.context: Degree of shared genetic material; does not guarantee cooperation without additional mechanisms like cellular competency.

concepts.name: Homeostasis
concepts.context: Maintenance of target physiological states through feedback control, enabling robust development and evolution.

concepts.name: Cybernetic Competency
concepts.context: Self-regulating control systems enabling goal-directed behavior at all biological scales.

concepts.name: Natural Induction
concepts.context: Framework seeking invariant principles between evolutionary processes and learning broadly construed.

concepts.name: Lamarckian Effects
concepts.context: Inheritance of acquired characteristics through cellular problem-solving and physiological response to novel stressors.

concepts.name: Scale-Free Biology
concepts.context: Integration of principles explaining biological organization at all scales from molecular to organismal.

concepts.name: Goal-Oriented Programming
concepts.context: Programming paradigm specifying desired outcomes rather than implementation details, mirroring biological competency architecture.

concepts.name: Autopoiesis
concepts.context: Self-maintaining organization of biological systems that define their own boundaries and internal structure.

concepts.name: Integrated Information
concepts.context: Measure of causal integration in systems; relevant to understanding consciousness and agency.

concepts.name: Coarse-Graining
concepts.context: Abstraction mechanism transforming low-level descriptions into higher-level models for downward causation.

concepts.name: Gene Regulatory Networks
concepts.context: Networks of genes and regulatory interactions implementing computational logic for cellular decision-making and memory.

concepts.name: Associative Memory
concepts.context: Capacity to link stimulus-response pairs, demonstrable in gene regulatory networks and transcriptional systems.

concepts.name: Hebbian Learning
concepts.context: Learning rule where correlated activity strengthens connections, operating at multiple biological scales.

concepts.name: Consciousness
concepts.context: Cellular consciousness proposed as primary source of biological order; present at fundamental biological scales.

concepts.name: Senome
concepts.context: Sensory-electronic genome; information-processing capacity of cells beyond genetic code.

concepts.name: Shape Homeostasis
concepts.context: Maintenance of target morphological states through homeostatic regulation mechanisms.

concepts.name: Developmental Memory
concepts.context: Phenotypic correlations reflecting developmental history and constraints on future evolutionary change.

concepts.name: Evo-Devo
concepts.context: Integration of evolutionary and developmental biology revealing how development enables evolutionary innovation.

concepts.name: Evolutionary Connectionism
concepts.context: Framework understanding evolution through connectionist principles and algorithmic organization of biological systems.

concepts.name: Evolutionary Individuality
concepts.context: Principles determining levels at which natural selection operates in hierarchy of biological organization.

concepts.name: Evolutionary Transitions In Individuality
concepts.context: Processes by which new levels of biological organization emerge through integration of previously independent units.

concepts.name: Extended Inheritance
concepts.context: Transmission of phenotypic traits beyond genetic code through epigenetic, behavioral, and ecological mechanisms.

concepts.name: Particle Plasticity
concepts.context: Adaptive variation at individual particle/component level affecting population-level outcomes.

concepts.name: Pleiotropy
concepts.context: Single gene affecting multiple traits, complicating credit assignment in evolution.

concepts.name: Morphological Coordination
concepts.context: Ancient ancestral function of cellular signaling coordinating body structure across nervous and non-nervous contexts.

concepts.name: Craniofacial Development
concepts.context: Development of head structures regulated by bioelectric patterns and cellular competency mechanisms.

concepts.name: Meta-Stability
concepts.context: Stochastic transitions between states in bioelectric circuits underlying pattern selection in regeneration.

concepts.name: Bioelectric Code
concepts.context: Ancient computational medium using ion channels and voltage gradients for control of growth and anatomical form.

concepts.name: Artificial Life
concepts.context: Field studying life-like behavior in computational systems, relevant to understanding universal principles of agency.

concepts.name: Artificial Embryogeny
concepts.context: Computational models of embryonic development used to understand morphogenetic principles.

concepts.name: Technological Approach To Mind Everywhere
concepts.context: Framework for understanding diverse forms of cognition across different embodiments using technological analysis.

concepts.name: Chromatin Computation
concepts.context: Information processing via chromatin structure and epigenetic states in cellular computation.

concepts.name: Free Energy Principle
concepts.context: Framework proposing that biological systems minimize free energy to maintain homeostasis; unifies thermodynamics, information theory, and cognition.

concepts.name: Markov Blankets
concepts.context: Conditional independence structure that defines boundaries of autonomous systems; used to analyze autonomy in biological and artificial systems.

concepts.name: Anatomical Homeostasis
concepts.context: Homeostatic regulation of body form and structure; suggests organisms maintain stable morphologies through goal-directed processes.

concepts.name: Associative Learning
concepts.context: Learning mechanism observable in simple organisms and chemical networks; demonstrates proto-cognitive capabilities in non-neural systems.

concepts.name: Agency
concepts.context: Capacity for goal-directed action and decision-making; extends beyond neural systems to cellular and evolutionary domains.

concepts.name: Nonlinearity
concepts.context: Essential property of biological regulation; enables complex responses, bistability, and emergent control without explicit hierarchical programming.

concepts.name: Left-Right Asymmetry
concepts.context: Asymmetric body organization controlled by bioelectric and serotonergic signals; occurs before neural development.

concepts.name: Membrane Potential (Vmem)
concepts.context: Ion-gradient-dependent electrical potential across cell membranes; encodes non-genetic information and enables bioelectric computation.

concepts.name: Cancer
concepts.context: Loss of anatomical homeostasis; disrupted bioelectric signaling; reversible through bioelectric reprogramming in model systems.

concepts.name: Minimal Intelligence
concepts.context: Cognitive capabilities in non-neural systems; found in bacteria, plants, and developmental morphogenesis.

concepts.name: Variational Ecology
concepts.context: Application of variational inference to ecological and consciousness phenomena; connects free energy principle to broader biological systems.

concepts.name: Hierarchically Mechanistic Mind
concepts.context: Evolutionary systems theory positing hierarchical organization of brain, cognition, and behavior; integrates mechanistic and evolutionary perspectives.

concepts.name: Cognitive Lens
concepts.context: Conceptual framework for analyzing cognition in development and regeneration; enables study of minimal intelligence in morphogenesis.

concepts.name: Xenopus Tadpole
concepts.context: Model organism for studying bioelectric signaling, regeneration, and developmental patterning; used in tumor induction and reversal studies.

concepts.name: Soft Robotics
concepts.context: Design and construction of flexible robots inspired by biological morphology; demonstrates morphological computation principles.

concepts.name: Reinforcement Learning
concepts.context: Machine learning paradigm for agents learning through reward signals; applicable to understanding adaptive behavior in biological systems.

concepts.name: Integration
concepts.context: Coordination and unity of bioelectric signals across multicellular aggregates; relates to consciousness and unified agency.

concepts.name: Minimal Developmental Computation
concepts.context: Causal network approach to understanding pattern formation; identifies minimal computational requirements for morphogenesis.

concepts.name: Free-Energy Approach To Pattern Regulation
concepts.context: Application of free energy principle to understanding morphogenetic pattern formation and organism localization.

concepts.name: Evolutionary Transitions In Individuality (ETIs)
concepts.context: Theory explaining transitions from solitary to multicellular organization; involves changes in information flow and level of selection.

frameworks.name: Variational Autoencoder Architecture
frameworks.context: Machine learning model using compression into generative code; parallels how genomes compress morphogenetic information across reproduction bottleneck.

frameworks.name: Bow-Tie Architecture
frameworks.context: Bottleneck structure in morphogenetic control exploiting bioelectric, biochemical, and biomechanical modalities as control nodes.

frameworks.name: Homeostatic Control Loop Model
frameworks.context: Framework treating development, regeneration, metamorphosis, and cancer suppression as manifestations of anatomical homeostasis.

frameworks.name: Multiscale Polycomputation Framework
frameworks.context: Model of problem-solving occurring simultaneously at multiple organizational scales in biological systems.

frameworks.name: Baldwin Effect Model
frameworks.context: Framework explaining how learned or physiologically plastic traits become canalized into genetic variation over time.

frameworks.name: Multiscale Competency Architecture
frameworks.creator: Michael Levin
frameworks.context: Model explaining how hierarchical problem-solving capacities at multiple biological scales enhance evolutionary search efficiency and enable morphological complexity.

frameworks.name: Active Inference Framework
frameworks.context: Cybernetic framework applied to biological systems for understanding how they minimize surprise through prediction and action.

frameworks.name: Homeostatic Control Loop
frameworks.context: Feedback mechanism with setpoint, measurement, comparison, and actuation components implementing goal-directed behavior at all scales.

frameworks.name: Test-Operate-Exit Loop
frameworks.context: Computational structure of homeostatic mechanisms enabling iterative problem-solving toward target states.

frameworks.name: Facilitated Variation Theory
frameworks.context: Framework describing how developmental mechanisms buffer variation and enable evolvability.

frameworks.name: Constructive Neutral Evolution Framework
frameworks.context: Model explaining evolutionary change through non-adaptive modifications to developmental control systems.

frameworks.name: Natural Induction Framework
frameworks.context: Emerging framework seeking universal principles connecting evolutionary and learning processes.

frameworks.name: Cybernetics
frameworks.context: Mathematical theory of feedback control and self-regulation applicable to biological systems at all scales.

frameworks.name: Object-Oriented Programming
frameworks.context: Computational paradigm using encapsulated objects with interfaces; mirrored in biological modular competencies.

frameworks.name: Free Energy Principle
frameworks.creator: Karl Friston
frameworks.context: Theoretical framework proposing biological systems minimize variational free energy; integrates thermodynamics, information theory, and cognition.

frameworks.name: Active Inference
frameworks.creator: Karl Friston
frameworks.context: Mechanism within free energy principle where agents act to fulfill predictions; explains perception-action loops.

frameworks.name: Markov Blankets Approach
frameworks.context: Formal method for defining system boundaries and autonomy; identifies minimal sufficient statistics for conditional independence.

frameworks.name: Hierarchically Mechanistic Mind
frameworks.creator: Badcock, Friston, Ramstead et al.
frameworks.context: Evolutionary systems theory explaining hierarchical organization of brain, cognition, and behavior through mechanistic principles.

frameworks.name: Variational Ecology
frameworks.creator: Ramstead et al.
frameworks.context: Extension of variational inference to ecological and consciousness phenomena; applies free energy principles broadly.

frameworks.name: Autopoiesis Theory
frameworks.context: Framework defining living systems as self-producing and self-maintaining; connects to autonomous agency and embodied cognition.

frameworks.name: Morphological Computation Framework
frameworks.creator: Rodney Pfeifer
frameworks.context: Model explaining how organism morphology and materials perform computational functions, reducing neural processing demands.

frameworks.name: Cognitive Lens Framework
frameworks.creator: Manicka and Levin
frameworks.context: Conceptual toolkit for analyzing cognition in developmental and regenerative morphogenesis; enables study of minimal intelligence.

frameworks.name: Minimal Developmental Computation
frameworks.creator: Manicka and Levin
frameworks.context: Causal network approach identifying minimal computational requirements for pattern formation and morphogenesis.

frameworks.name: Evolutionary Transitions In Individuality Theory
frameworks.creator: Maynard Smith and Szathmáry
frameworks.context: Framework explaining major evolutionary transitions through changes in information flow and level of selection.

frameworks.name: Waddington's Landscape Model
frameworks.creator: Conrad Waddington
frameworks.context: Conceptual model of development as trajectory through landscape of possible states; connects to chreods and epigenetic regulation.

institutions.name: Allen Discovery Center
institutions.context: Center at Tufts University directed by Michael Levin; focuses on morphogenesis, regeneration, and xenobots.

institutions.name: Tufts University
institutions.context: Host institution for Allen Discovery Center and much of the research discussed in this paper.

institutions.name: Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering
institutions.context: Harvard-affiliated institute where Michael Levin holds position; focuses on bio-inspired engineering and regenerative medicine.

institutions.name: Harvard University
institutions.context: Host institution for Wyss Institute and related bioengineering research.

institutions.name: John Templeton Foundation
institutions.context: Funding organization supporting research including the work presented in this paper on competency and evolutionary innovation.

institutions.name: MIT Press
institutions.context: Publisher of major works on evolution, artificial life, and consciousness referenced in bibliography.

questions.question: What are the features of morphogenesis that enable evolution to search difficult phenotype space efficiently despite pleiotropy, degeneracy, and redundancy?
questions.context: Central question about evolutionary problem-solving; paper proposes competency and hacking of cellular affordances as key features.

questions.question: How can evolution be so rapid and effective at using mutation to address opportunities of form and function despite rugged fitness landscapes?
questions.context: Addresses apparent paradox of evolutionary speed; paper argues competency-based search of behavior-shaping signals rather than genotype microstates.

questions.question: How do we explain the ubiquitous presence of novel capabilities in living things for which no direct selection forces are plausible?
questions.context: Asks about adaptation vs. byproducts; paper suggests general-purpose problem-solving machinery creates unexpected capacities.

questions.question: What determines which genotypes must be altered to produce specific large-scale anatomical features and functional outcomes?
questions.context: Inverse problem in biomedical engineering; paper argues solution requires understanding morphogenetic competencies, not just molecular details.

questions.question: How is the target morphology or homeostatic setpoint represented and stored in biological systems?
questions.context: Fundamental question about biological information; paper proposes bioelectric patterns as primary representational medium.

questions.question: What mechanisms allow cells to scale up from individual competencies to collective problem-solving in larger and more complex problem spaces?
questions.context: Question about emergence of higher-level intelligence; paper proposes gap junctions, tissue signaling, and information sharing as mechanisms.

questions.question: How can organisms with extremely variable or messy genomes (like planaria) exhibit superior morphological control compared to organisms with stable genomes?
questions.context: Puzzle resolved by evolutionary intelligence ratchet theory and competency-based rather than hardwiring-based development.

questions.question: What is the relationship between cellular plasticity and robustness to cancer, aging, and injury?
questions.context: Counter-intuitive question; paper proposes that high morphogenetic competency serves multiple functions through error minimization.

questions.question: How do bioelectric networks store and manipulate morphogenetic memories independent of genetic sequence?
questions.context: Questions nature of biological memory; paper demonstrates planarian head-number and head-shape reprogramming via bioelectric circuits.

questions.question: Can evolution exploit physiological and morphogenetic plasticity to bias evolutionary search in adaptive directions?
questions.context: Questions whether Baldwin effect applies to developmental plasticity; paper suggests this occurs via competency mechanisms.

questions.question: How do molecular events triggered by a stimulus become expanded into complex nervous system architecture that controls behavior?
questions.context: Fundamental question about scaling of biological information across multiple levels of organization from molecular to behavioral.

questions.question: What are the latent spaces of homeodynamic goals at different biological scales, and where do these setpoints originate?
questions.context: Probing the origins and nature of goal states underlying biological computation across diverse scales.

questions.question: How can cells solve the credit assignment problem to determine which genes to modify in response to novel physiological stressors?
questions.context: Question about cellular computational mechanisms enabling adaptive response to unprecedented challenges.

questions.question: To what degree does evolution search in the space of behavior-shaping signals versus low-dimensional hardware specifications?
questions.context: Fundamental question about the nature of the space evolutionary processes actually explore.

questions.question: How can we detect and measure problem-solving capacities in systems not known for their competency?
questions.context: Challenge in identifying intelligence and agency in unexpected biological contexts across model systems.

questions.question: What are the bidirectional relationships between multiscale intelligence and evolutionary processes?
questions.context: Question about feedback loops between cognitive scaling and evolutionary innovation.

questions.question: Can cells implement reverse central dogma—determining which genes to edit based on physiological state?
questions.context: Whether cellular computation can solve inverse biological engineering problems through transcriptional mechanisms.

questions.question: How do affordances and competencies enable bioengineers and evolution to achieve complex outcomes?
questions.context: Question about practical exploitation of biological problem-solving in engineering design.

questions.question: How does cellular competency and bioelectric signaling enable morphogenetic intelligence without centralized neural control?
questions.context: Central to understanding non-neural cognition and pattern formation in development and regeneration.

questions.question: Can anatomical homeostasis and morphological goal-directedness be reversed through bioelectric reprogramming?
questions.context: Tests whether developmental patterns are locked or remain fluid; has implications for cancer reversal and regenerative medicine.

questions.question: What is the minimal hardware and computational architecture required for consciousness or minimal intelligence?
questions.context: Bridges AI, cognitive science, and developmental biology; questions boundaries of psychological properties.

questions.question: How do bioelectric networks store and transmit non-genetic patterning information across generations?
questions.context: Explores information storage beyond DNA; challenges central dogma and illuminates developmental memory mechanisms.

questions.question: Does the Free Energy Principle adequately explain morphogenesis and pattern formation in biological systems?
questions.context: Evaluates whether variational inference frameworks extend from neuroscience to developmental and evolutionary biology.

questions.question: Can soft robots and xenobots exhibit genuine agency and goal-directed behavior through morphological computation?
questions.context: Questions whether artificial systems can replicate autonomy and purposefulness of biological entities; relevant to AI alignment.

questions.question: What are the evolutionary advantages of diverse morphological computations across different body plans?
questions.context: Explores evolvability and innovation through morphology-based information processing.

questions.question: How do individual cells exhibit associative learning and adaptive behavior in chemical networks?
questions.context: Challenges distinctions between single-cell and multicellular cognition; expands definition of learning.
